reviewText:
For those that missed the first episode of Sonic 4, this is a 2D platforming game staring everyone's favorite blue hedgehog. The plot is the same as its always been, but with a twist. Dr. Robotnik, the evil antagonist of most every Sonic game has now teamed up with Metal Sonic! The dude with 90s attitude isn't alone though, he now has Tails to go with him. With Tails, come new mechanics, such as jumping into the air, and calling Tails to lift Sonic like a helicopter. If you're on the ground and use the tag button, it summons Tails to combine the two for a super fast attack. If you need to use the helicopter ability, the game will have a little billboard to tell you. This game feels more a kin to the Game Boy Advance games than the original Genesis games which the first episode clearly drew inspiration from.

In Episode 2, you have four zones with three acts each followed by a boss fight as a fourth act. Not just that, but later into the four hour game, you unlock a playable Metal Sonic with four zones and one act each. These zones use assets from the first episode. So in all, there are 16+ levels for you to master. These levels feel a lot longer than the first episode and the Genesis games as a whole. Some levels feel like six minute marathons with no end in sight.

The levels are big and offer many paths to the exit. You'll have to avoid an array of enemies, spikes, and even death traps. You'll collect rings everywhere and these rings aren't just because dullards love shinny things, but as long as Sonic has at least one ring, he can take another hit. Even if you have 100 rings and get hit, only 30 will spray out of Sonic. When you get hit with no rings, it means death for the fuzzy blue guy. There are plenty of check points in each level if you die. A game over simply means that you'll need to start the level again. If you collect 100 rings in a level, you get an extra life. If you have 50+ rings at the end of the level, a giant ring will appear that will take you to a special bonus stage.

These bonus stages are updated versions of the old Sonic 2 bonus stages. You'll follow Sonic running down a 3D half pipe. You can boost and jump. There are a few check points that need X amount of rings to get past. So as Sonic, you'll solemn down the tube moving left and right, collecting rings and dodging obstacles that will lose you rings. At the end you'll find a chaos emerald.... that somehow isn't green. Whatever. Collect all seven to unlock a yellow Super Sonic.

New to the Sonic 4 series is local co-op and even online co-op, but since the game came out in 2011, good luck trying to find a partner. There are online leader boards for time attacks. It adds to the replayability I guess, but more than that, the game has a red star ring on each level to collect. These rings are either tough to find or tough to get. Its an extra challenge for veterans.Sonic and Metal Sonic play the same. Left and right to move, with a single button to jump. Hold down to duck and hit the jump button to start a spin dash to get momentum to go up slopes. You still need to charge it which takes time. That's why the airborne dart attack is not only a much better way to gain speed instantly, but you can also lock in on targets accurately hit them no matter what the angle. Episode 2 didn't make as much use of the homing attack as the first episode, but it does make travel easier, darting for an enemy or a springboard. The only difference between Metal Sonic and the ordinary version is lack of an ally. No helicoptering around or bowling through enemies.

Calling Tails just feels slow. Tails automatically zips right back to Sonic wherever he is, unless he just died, but it just halts the game to wait. The Sky Fortress kicks off with an airplane mission that has Sonic atop Tail's plane that gives you full control to move the plane left, right, up and down. Complete with Sonic able to jump and attack. Under normal circumstances, I'd think it diversifies gameplay having a plane dodge enemies and twirl through barricades to destroy them. This felt like a slow auto scrolling level (act). There was still a part where the 2D platforming returned, but then it was just back to being on top of a plane. It felt dull, slow and boring. Then having to fight the boss on the plane was unfun.

The real snag that I have for this game is how long and dull the boss battles are. They take traditional, classic boss battles and completely twist them around into mega bosses. See I like the twists and fighting giant bosses, I just don't like how tedious every boss was. Having to damage each boss for three minutes before the final phase of the boss fight left me clueless and dead ate up most of my 4 hours in the game. These 3 minutes on each attempt felt like 10 and I was never in any real danger. It wasn't a challenge surviving the 3 minutes, it was just a delay for the real challenge. At least the game takes full advantage of having Metal Sonic as an enemy. You get three boss fights against him.

The game has other down sides too, like a timed race against sand flooding an area. Sonic needs to go up, breaking through barriers, then down. This would separate the casual players from the hardcore. It ate up two dozen lives and was quite the difficulty spike. Then on the final two levels, when Sonic went down hill or uphill, the entire screen would shift so Sonic wasn't running downhill, he was on a horizontal plane. It was disorienting, and might cause someone motion sickness.

Water areas feel better in this game than they have in the past. Sonic jumps higher and Tails can carry him, so you have more maneuverability. Under water still slows down Sonic and he can't swim. If you're underwater too long, Sonic will need to get oxygen from big air bubbles that drift their way up.
The soundtrack feels Genesis in a good way. Percussion and synth horns. Its all upbeat happy game music. The graphics are bright and vibrant. There is a good color pallet here. A dusty yellow castle with an aquatic greenish blue moat. A winter wonderland theme park, lit up for a holiday with blue ice water. A metallic sandy red oil rig in a yellow desert. A yellow sky fortress with fans to propel Sonic into the air. Dr. Robotnik's gray and purple metal lair. As each zone progressed, the acts would change their color pallets so you'll see day turn to dusk. It all adds to making each of the three acts feel different. Having Metal Sonic's 4 different zones with 1 act each adds a lot of diversity, even if 3 acts each would have been nicer.

Even with all the bad, its still a good game. Better than most other 2D platforms out there for $15. I enjoyed the first episode better, but it felt like they took the gameplay a step in the right direction. If its on sale, take a risk.

reviewText: I want to get this out of the way before starting this review, why was this episodic? This easily could've been the next main series Sonic game as Episode 2 looks WAY different than Episode 1. But was it for the best? Yes. Another problem in Episode 1 was unoriginality, which Episode 2 changes around (apart from Not Wing Fortress Zone). The bosses are now not complete jokes but I found the Eggman bosses annoying and enduring complete with a 17 second loop boss theme. I have much more enjoyment with the Metal Sonic fight in White Park before Sky Fortress ruined his reputation. The music is still Mega Drive samples but I found more catchy tunes in this game than Episode 1. Also, this game has Tails who follows Sonic like in Sonic 2 and you can perform tag actions with him, like flying, swimming underwater and 69. So is this an improvement over Episode 1? In my opinion, yes. Still not worthy of the name Sonic 4 but it's a decent improvement. 8/10

reviewText:
Sonic 4 Episode 2 is a game I'm completely inconsistent with. I played it for half an hour and thought it wasn't worth playing through, played it again from beginning to end and hated it, and then played it through again and honestly thought it was on par with the Genesis games.

In comparison to Episode 1 it's definitely better. The physics are improved and the graphics no longer look like New Super Mario Bros. but worse. A lot of people complained that classic Sonic was absent from the first game, and took it way overboard, but I kinda do agree that modern looks really unnatural here. Thankfully there's a mod for that anyway if it bothers you that much.

The game controls a lot better than Ep1 and it's at least satisfying in this game, but still not quite as solid as in the classic games or even Generations. Sonic feels like he lacks weight on the ground and momentum building isn't quite right, sometimes requiring homing attack spamming just to reach your max speed on the ground.

The level themes are all blatantly reused concepts with the exception of White Park which while I can compare it to some levels it doesn't outright copy anything. I hate the fact that a game selling itself as Sonic 4 is almost nothing but recycled levels and enemies, but the levels themselves have so many new concepts that it's still pretty fresh as a whole, and the likenesses of Episode 2's levels to classic levels isn't as offensive as in Ep1... with the exception of Sky Fortress which is nearly identical.

The game's visuals are absolutely gorgeous. I'd say Sonic 4 Ep2 is the most scenic game in the series. It's incredibly polished visually. I can't say the same about the soundtrack, though. While I initially really hated it, I realized on subsequent playthroughs with Super Sonic available I never used him for just one reason; I didn't want to stop the level music. While I do actually really love the compositions themselves, the instrumentation is horrid. They clearly went for a Genesis style tinny-ness to the synths but it just sounds awful on some tracks, specifically Sky Fortress Act II and the Death Egg's theme, two songs which I would actually really like if they used better synths.

Oh yeah it's also really short. This game has five zones in total and 25 levels in all if you count the boss levels and special stages. I think with a casual runthrough of both this and Sonic 2, Sonic 2 would still be longer, but I consider Sonic 2 to be fairly short for a Sonic game I dunno. Completing the game without all of the Chaos Emeralds yields a message to go collect them, but there's really no reason to, because it does nothing to the ending. Little Planet is still stuck inside the Death Egg while Sonic and Tails feel good about themselves in their escape pods. This could be thought of as a lead-in to Episode 3, but as of now Sega has no plans for one. One of the developers has said that they might make one if Ep2 sold well. Did it? I dunno but I certainly don't want the Sonic 4 series to end like this.

The game was actually short enough that I turned to achievement hunting to elongate it. Which was odd as this was after I'd already had my fill of this game and dismissed it as another bad Sonic entry. I actually WANTED to come back to collect achievements and actually found a lot of fun with the game, both in gathering the achievements and just playing the game itself. However I will say that the achievements are absolutely pointless. Certain gameplay elements like the Red Rings and presence and abundance of rings before boss encounters were clearly just implemented for the game's achievements on release, but getting said achievements has no bearing on the actual game whatsoever. Collecting all the Red Rings or getting the last hit on every boss as Super Sonic, none of this affects the game at all. It doesn't even have a list of the achievements in game so really it's questionable why they're even there other than to make this short game slightly longer.

All in all though I did find a lot of fun with this. The game's length as well as reused settings are the biggest problems, but they're pretty well made up for with a beautiful presentation, pretty enjoyable music and most of all a lot of good level gimmicks and physical designs. Is it as good as the classics? Eh, probably not, if only because it's not completely orginal, but I had just about as much fun with it anyway.

reviewText:
Sonic the Hedgehog, that little blue ball of fur. He whizzes around in a blur. Faster than a speeding bullet. The thrill! The exhilaration!

Those wonderful feelings that come to mind whenever I think of Sonic and his buddies. When thinking of a character like Sonic, it's hard to separate nostalgia from true feelings. Hopefully I'll be able to do that!

Sonic 4: E2 is a fun platformer. Colourful landscapes, and cute enemies create a vibrant atmosphere. The graphics are acceptable for a 2D game in this generation. The game struggles to run on low end machines, even those that pass the system requirements. The game just isn't playable with system lag, or low FPS.

The gameplay is okay, but I do have a few issues. To me Sonic was a different kind of platformer. It was all about whizzing through the levels as fast as possible. I got great joy from timing my jumps just right, getting enough coins for the special levels and bouncing off the enemies on the way. Unfortunately S4E2 doesn't feel right. Sonic at full speed feels sluggish, and that's a word you never want associated with our heroic hedgehog. I never felt out of control, Sonic never flew off the screen. Some people might call that a good thing, but I think a fair few fans would agree with my perspective.

I was able to play some levels co-op. The levels are the same, one player controls Sonic, the other Tails. The problem with co-op is as soon as one character gets a little bit away from the other, the player behind has to use the catch up button. This just made the game feel like a chaotic mess. However, this chaotic mess was extremely fun. It enabled some awesome near-death escapes.

The game is trying hard to be like the 2D Sonic games of old. It introduces some new abilities, like forming a super-ball of death with Tails (which is the best way to go through 80% of levels), or dashing through the air by double jumping. Ultimately this is where it fails. It's an okay platformer, and it has a pricepoint that reflects the length of the game but it doesn't stand up to classic Sonic games.

Whilst the game does not stand up against previous Sonic games, it is quite a fun platformer. The levels are a nice length and fun to run through once. There isn't much replayability there though.

Bottom Line: Fun co-op game. A little lacklustre when compared to classic Sonic.

The music, like for all Sonic games, is very well done and feels very fitting. Every single stage sounds appropriate, from White Park Zone sounding very much like a snowy wonderland to Oil Desert Zone sounding like an intimidating desert factory. The music itself is composed fantastically, with nothing in it that would grate on the ears, and even the new power-up music doesn't sound too bad.

The controls and physics take some getting used to, especially if you haven't played a game with Sonic's acceleration need; thankfully, it's been improved somewhat from Episode 1, making it less bothersome. Hey look, it's Sonic 2 HD!

If you've played Sonic 4 Episode 1, you'll probably guess that this game is probably as bad as the first one, and you would be 75% correct. Sonic 4 Episode 2 is yet another dissapointing release in the never ending Dark Ages of Sonic, which is an on-going line of bad Sonic games starting from 2006, and this one has joined the bandwagon.

Instead of being based off Sonic 1, this one is based off Sonic 2 and rightly so, only because it has Tails in it.

The gameplay is not too shabby and it is actually better than the first one, but it still has some kinks. The physics are still kind of bad but not as bad as Episode 1. There's also no copying of any of the previous zones from old Sonic games, but some zones are similar to other zones seen in the Sonic series, but I can't really list them all.

The story is really hard to notice due to all of the characters refusing to talk during the entire game, in all seriousness a storyline isn't really here in this game.

This game relies way too heavily on the special Sonic + Tails moves, most of the game requires you to use those moves. Like in Oil Desert Zone act 2 or 3, the end of the act requires you to use the flying-Tails-carrying-Sonic thing for the rest of the act, and I've died a few times in that part.

The Co-op mode is ok, and suprisingly it is accurate to Sonic 2's co-op mode: You both have to stay on the same gosh darn screen.

It's still not a worthy sequel to the Sega Genesis Sonic we all know and love, but it is slightly better than episode 1. This game is really only for bored gamers waiting for something interesting to happen and for crazy Sonic fans who collect every Sonic game known in exsistance both good and bad.

4.7/10

Metal Sonic: maximum good

The art assets: A magnificent transition of classic sonic stage elements reimagined in 3D, every stage is a nostalgic combination of themes I fondly remember as a child.

The zones: Three acts per zone, though with substantually more variety in both the mechanics employed by the stage and the art assets and set pieces uses to create the surroundings. It's a more lovingly crafted subtle progression than previous games were able to render.

The special stages: Out of seven the first five are amazing. Prepare to smash your face against the monitor as you retry the last two relentlessly. FORTNUATELY you can restart the special stages if you know you're going to fail without the arduous task of beating a level with 50 rings, dodged a real bullet there Sega.

The bosses: Suprisingly inspired (for the most part), they employ using cooperative attacks with tails.

Tails: No longer sabotaging your special stages. There's a rather large startup delay for the Sonic/Tails combination attacks and going SSJ I mean Super Sonic was a bit jarring. While flying with him he is prone to dropping sonic if you shear the two of them on a cliff's edge while trying to scale it. He will literally pull a Yoshi on Sonic by dropping him into an endless void pit unless you soar overtop the edge.

A game has to be fairly unbearable for me to not want to finish it.  Well, congratulations Sonic 4, you've landed in that small list of games I just straight up hate.

The parts that broke me?  Lots of them, but most specifically the Oil world part 2: the  Oil world has a mechanci where you run across sinking sand and have to jump in order to not sink into it and die, right?  Fine, that's fair.  At a certain point in the stage I was then forced to run along this sand, but in a low corridor where while on top of the sand Sonic's head would be touching the roof of the corridor.  This immediately slowed my progress to a grinding halt.  It gets better, though, because as you get further down the corridor, the roof is raised BUT Spikes are placed at the bottom of the roof!  The spike tips reach exactly where the ceiling of the corridor was before, so if you jump too high you just die.  This isn't ok but I could have at least gotten through the area if it wasn't very, very long or if there had been any rings whatsoever in it, but no, I got hit once, all of my rings disappeared in the sand, and then I had to go through the rest of this insanely long corridor without any protection.  ♥♥♥♥ that.

The boss of the Winter world -- really cool looking level by the way -- was also full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Alright, cool, I'm racing Metal Sonic and I have to catch up with him and hit him, awesome!  This is awesome!  Wait, two minutes into the fight -- seemed like a long time for a sonic game -- he just hits the platform that I'm running on, breaking it.  I immediately ran into the hole and fell to my death, restarting the fight.  Alright, whatever, that was really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t because I didn't have the time to react, and it's dumb that I have to restart the boss fight but at least I know that's coming now and it won't happen again.  Oh wait no, he just does that attack so fast and it's right on top of where you're running that you're just ♥♥♥♥ed if you don't anticipate it.

Elsewhere in poor design land is anything to do with Tails.  Alright, so you occassionally have to press a button to join up with Tails for a special ability.  Cool.  Except for, you know, these abilities being so limited in utility that the only times you use them are when the game halts your progress unless you use the abilities.  Of course, you use them so infrequently that if you hit these parts, you won't know what to do, so the game has to put up a sign telling you which ability you need to use to progress.  Hey game, if you think I can't figure something out because I'm not using it frequently enough then I'm pretty sure you designed these abilities poorly.

Tl;dr: there are some cool parts to the game but they usually get ♥♥♥♥ed up with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ design, horrible enemy placement and just straight up terrible choices.

No, ♥♥♥♥ this game.  It's not a good game and it's not a good sonic game.  Just don't waste your time.

Game: Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 2
Genre: Adventure
Developer: Sonic Team/SEGA
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 90/100
Value Score: 90/10

• Story: 8/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 2 takes place a few months after the events of Episode 1. Little Planet from Sonic CD makes a return. Dr. Eggman who was secretly planning a bigger plot from Episode 1 has events set out for Episode 2 - plans he had since Episode 1. As Dr. Eggman heads out to carry out his plans he discovers that Little Planet is coming near their world and decides to reawaken Metal Sonic who was left after his defeat from Sonic CD (which more than confirms that Sonic CD takes place Sonic 3). After being revived Metal Sonic decided to explore through the old stages of Episode 1 to obtain a sacred power that he had sensed. After obtaining the power he has more than become capable of matching with Sonic in terms of Power. After encountering Dr. Eggman along with the reawakened Metal Sonic, Sonic has decided to recruit back his buddy Tails to help him defeat the duo.

• Characters: 9/10
o Tails and Metal Sonic makes a return after being absent from Episode 1 - Sonic and Dr. Eggman make a return as well. New enemies have been added to the mix along with some remakes of the first enemies from the first few games as well.

• GamePlay: 10/10
o Episode 2 continues off the gameplay scheme as Episode 1 but includes a few new nice additions thanks to the inclusion of Tails. Sonic and Tails can do team moves which can range from flying with Tails and rolling into obstacles. Players who have a original file from Episode 1 can also unlock Episode Metal which is a expansion of Episode 1 but you play as Metal Sonic in the game who plays more like Episode 1's sonic without the help of a secondary combo skills (via Tails). Zones and acts return like the other Sonic games, check point posts allow you to come back at that point rather than starting all over again, and now Red Star Rings have been added which is equivalent to a Koopa/Dinosaur coin from Super Mario World. All of the power ups from the first game also make a return.

• Graphics: 10/10
o Just like in Episode 1, Episode 2's visual design is amazingly well done with all the lighting, shading and texture detailing. Episode 2 uses the same engine as Episode 1.

• Sound: 10/10
o Episode 2 uses the same sound effects in quality and bitrate as the first sonic game. A lot more of the old sound effects have returned thanks to the inclusion of tails and new sound effects relating to Metal Sonic have been added as well.

• Music: 9/10
o Episode 2 uses similar if not the same tracks as the first game but also includes several new tracks related to the new stages. You also have several remixes of older games such as the racing level from Sonic CD against Metal Sonic.

• Length: 6/10
o Episode 2 is a bit longer than Episode 1 however it is as short in terms of completion. Excluding Episode Metal, the game should take you about 3-4 hours to complete. There are about 5 zones with 2-3 acts each. If you include Episode Metal you get 4 additional levels (no bosses or additional acts).

• Replay Value: 8/10
o The amount of stages and the inclusion of special stages have added more to the replay value along with the fact that you can now play multiplayer with a friend and do some of the newly added challenges that related to the racing/time of the levels (which did not exist in the first game).

• Player Value: 10/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 2 is a great improvement of the first game with adding a bit more to the storyline and action in the game. A far more variety as well has been added to the overall design along with the fact that there is a nice addition of two returning characters with one character being a focus with a remake of the first episode's levels in its core storyline. The new Team combo system adds a bit more to the overall gameplay that you never experienced in a Sonic game and thanks to the visual design and the ear relaxing music this game is a instant buy for any Platformer and Sonic lover. The game also adds a bit more challenges and replay options that were missing from the first game.

This IS actually a recommendation, but from someone who did somewhat enjoy Episode I, so keep that in mind.

• Story: 8/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 2 takes place a few months after the events of Episode 1. Little Planet from Sonic CD makes a return. Dr. Eggman who was secretly planning a bigger plot from Episode 1 has events set out for Episode 2 - plans he had since Episode 1. As Dr. Eggman heads out to carry out his plans he discovers that Little Planet is coming near their world and decides to reawaken Metal Sonic who was left after his defeat from Sonic CD (which more than confirms that Sonic CD takes place Sonic 3). After being revived Metal Sonic decided to explore through the old stages of Episode 1 to obtain a sacred power that he had sensed. After obtaining the power he has more than become capable of matching with Sonic in terms of Power. After encountering Dr. Eggman along with the reawakened Metal Sonic, Sonic has decided to recruit back his buddy Tails to help him defeat the duo.

• Characters: 9/10
o Tails and Metal Sonic makes a return after being absent from Episode 1 - Sonic and Dr. Eggman make a return as well. New enemies have been added to the mix along with some remakes of the first enemies from the first few games as well.

• GamePlay: 10/10
o Episode 2 continues off the gameplay scheme as Episode 1 but includes a few new nice additions thanks to the inclusion of Tails. Sonic and Tails can do team moves which can range from flying with Tails and rolling into obstacles. Players who have a original file from Episode 1 can also unlock Episode Metal which is a expansion of Episode 1 but you play as Metal Sonic in the game who plays more like Episode 1's sonic without the help of a secondary combo skills (via Tails). Zones and acts return like the other Sonic games, check point posts allow you to come back at that point rather than starting all over again, and now Red Star Rings have been added which is equivalent to a Koopa/Dinosaur coin from Super Mario World. All of the power ups from the first game also make a return.

• Graphics: 10/10
o Just like in Episode 1, Episode 2's visual design is amazingly well done with all the lighting, shading and texture detailing. Episode 2 uses the same engine as Episode 1.

• Sound: 10/10
o Episode 2 uses the same sound effects in quality and bitrate as the first sonic game. A lot more of the old sound effects have returned thanks to the inclusion of tails and new sound effects relating to Metal Sonic have been added as well.

• Music: 9/10
o Episode 2 uses similar if not the same tracks as the first game but also includes several new tracks related to the new stages. You also have several remixes of older games such as the racing level from Sonic CD against Metal Sonic.

• Length: 6/10
o Episode 2 is a bit longer than Episode 1 however it is as short in terms of completion. Excluding Episode Metal, the game should take you about 3-4 hours to complete. There are about 5 zones with 2-3 acts each. If you include Episode Metal you get 4 additional levels (no bosses or additional acts).

• Replay Value: 8/10
o The amount of stages and the inclusion of special stages have added more to the replay value along with the fact that you can now play multiplayer with a friend and do some of the newly added challenges that related to the racing/time of the levels (which did not exist in the first game).

• Player Value: 10/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode 2 is a great improvement of the first game with adding a bit more to the storyline and action in the game. A far more variety as well has been added to the overall design along with the fact that there is a nice addition of two returning characters with one character being a focus with a remake of the first episode's levels in its core storyline. The new Team combo system adds a bit more to the overall gameplay that you never experienced in a Sonic game and thanks to the visual design and the ear relaxing music this game is a instant buy for any Platformer and Sonic lover. This game is a bit of a mixed bag.  Sega fixed the problems from episode 1 with the way Sonic moves and tried some new ideas, but a number of them failed miserably.

The good things first:  The graphics are definitely improved and they got rid of the ugly fake 16 bit look from Sonic.  Sonic moves better and doesn't feel so sluggish.  Sega tried a lot of new ideas and came up with some pretty unique levels which are a pretty nice change from previous games.

Now the bad:  A lot of that new unique stuff is terrible, flow breaking, and annoying.  Some new enemies seem to be designed to always hit you if you're going fast like Sonic should.  Some parts of the new level designs are rather annoying, especially the way they ham-fisted the Tails combo abilities in.  In order to reach the fast path in a lot of levels you seem to be required to use Tails' flying ability to reach places you can't even see.  There's also a combo rolling attack which is required to break down some barriers.  The game prompts you every time you're required to use them to continue in the level, and they mainly serve as an annoyance.  And the other problem with the levels...they actually added a scrolling level in the game.  That's right, in a game where the whole point is to be as fast as possible, they added a slow scroller (and Sonic becomes extremely sluggish on this level as well).

Now the biggest problem with the game: the bosses.  Without exception, the bosses are all extremely annoying and tedious fights.  Bosses are a lot more complicated than previous games, take many more hits to kill, and of course require Tails combo abilities at certain not-so-obvious spots.  They also tend to have very long start and transition sequences that you have to wait through every time if you fail.  One of the bosses even uses the scrolling level set up to make it as annoying as humanly possible to fight him.

I got to the final boss, and fighting him is so annoying that I can't even be bothered to finish the game.  Do yourself a favor and just get Episode 1 and Generations.  This one isn't worth it.

reviewText:
Don’t be put off by the game’s lack of commercial success. First it should be said the both parts of Sonic 4, Episode 1 (4.1) and Episode 2 (4.2) seem to have an identity crisis. They are officially sequels but in reality they are something of an updated remake, 4.1 and 4.2 borrow and reference Sonic 1, 2, 3&K and CD heavily; 4.1s bosses are all remakes of the originals, a fault 4.2 even references with the first boss originally appearing to mimic the Aquatic Ruins’ Boss before transforming into something new. However even it borrows the later levels and boss fights. The level design 4.2 is also much better than 4.1’s. As 4.2 has original zones; Sylvanian Castle, Winter Park Zone and the Oil Desert (whose features resemble 3&K’s Sandopolis much more than Sonic 2’s Oil Ocean which it would appear to be a copy of at first glance). After this 4.2 does fall into copying the final zone which is just an amalgamation of Wing Fortress, Sky Chase and the Flying Battery zones, taking features from each but making them worse (in the Sky Chase knock off for example Tail’s Plane can disappear leaving the player plummeting to earth).

There are problems with both games; they both insist on the use of Sonic’s homing attack to access ledges which I find it unnecessary for a side-scroller. Again Physics does not seem to apply in Sonic the Hedgehog’s universe, he can walk up walls when travelling at fairly low speeds (although not as badly as he could in 06), while the homing attack creates momentum from nothing.

Even the traditional saving grace of the Sonic game, the soundtrack, is poor which is disappointing. In addition, the game also has a very short life span, 4.1 failed to keep me attached for more than 5 hours, and while 4.2 actually saw me to completion, it only has at most 5-12 hours of gameplay depending on how quickly you can master it and I doubt either has much in the way of replay value unlike the games they are based upon.

This said however, for once Sonic actually controls well (which he never does in 3D Games). 4.2 itself still contains a number of very good features. The inclusion of team mechanics was a great idea as it makes Tails a valued partner to Sonic, his abilities have made him an essential part as he can get Sonic through traps and defeat opponents. 4.2 also did well with the special stages, which like 4.1s are copies of the original games (this time the tunnel runs of Sonic 2,) unlike 4.1 however, 4.2 improves the originals. Tails is no longer a dead weight, he doesn't drop rings when hit and a new power up (a chaotix ring type feature) can give new interesting challenges, it is just a pity they weren’t used more often.

Therefore although neither are great like the games they were trying to emulate, they are ok and I generally do not see why they have been so badly received as they’re worthy successors to the original Sonic. 4.1 may be distinctly average but 4.2 is a big improvement upon it. The current price tags are not value for money but if you pick them up in the Steam sale (as I did) 4.2 is certainly worth a fiver. 4.1 should only be purchased if you want the bonus Metal Sonic Mode which works when you own both parts.

So Sonic 4: Ep.1 was a bit of a letdown condidering how much hype it got (you can go check out my ep.1 review as well). So SEGA a year and half later came out with Sonic The Hedgehog 4: Episode 2. Or in other words the LAST episode in the sonic 4 saga.

Well storywize. Sonic meets up with Tails and he says that little planet from Sonic CD would be making its annual return. But Sonic scences that Eggman is once again up to no good and they hop in the tornado and go see the commotion. Well Little Planet this time decided to be a) much larger and b) appear in space this time. Suddenly they run into Metal Sonic. Why is he here? Its explained later. After taking down Eggmans flying ship he reveals that he used little planet as the bases for his new base the Death Egg MK.2. After taking down Metal Sonic and destroying the heart Sonic and Tails barely escape the death egg and..... thats it. What the ♥♥♥♥ was that? The death egg remains intact, little planet is still trapped inside and we still dont know how metal sonic got there? What kind of ♥♥♥♥ id That?

Okay gameplay. So Sonic now has Tails follow him around the stages and by pressing the X button they can do a co-op move that depends were you activate it in the air or underwater Tails carrys sonic to safety and on the ground they charge up a super spin dash and obliterate enemies. I tgink this is a pretty cool idea. But you can decide which character is the lead. You always play as Sonic, not my idea why cant I play as tails? Sonic can still do all the things he can do in Ep.1 but the physics have been improved tremondously over ep.1 and rolling is now a good use in means of gaining speed as well. we even get some creative uses of the homing attack instead of just enemie chains (which there is also much less of them as well). There are still a fair amout of speed boosters but definitely less than ep.1. The stages themself are much more orifional that ep.1 so we Have Slyvania Castle Zone, White Park Zone, NOT-Oil Ocean Zone (Oil Desert Zone) and NOT-Wing Fortress Zone (Sky Fortrress Zone). Like ep.1 while some level themes may be reused the level design is differnt. The level design definitely feels less barren that ep.1, still a bit rough around the edges but nothing ill lose sleep over. Well what about those special stages? Well like ep.1 if you collect 50 rings and jump into the ring at the end you'll be transported to the special stage. The special stages are similer to the sonic 2, Sonic Pocket adveture, Sonic Ruch and Sonic Colours DS as you run along a halfpipe and collect a certen amout of rings. Get enought you get a chaos emerald and you can play as super sonic in regular stages withc is always nice. In terms of bosses well this is the games weakness... when your not fighting eggman your fighting metal sonic. Eggmans bosses, while origonal, are bad. They overstay their welcome by about 3 minuits and the looping 6 times per minuite music doesnt help. The metal sonic fight are thankfully much better, expecialy the white park boss I always get a kik out of that. as I said before all the bosses in this game are origonal apart from the 4th and final encounter with metal sonic being a remake of the race from Sonic CD. The finlal boss is at best ok, but I just wish there was more to it.

In terms of looks, this game excells. While i dont mind how ep.1 looks, but this is soo much better and the result is one fantastic looking game. Music is better than ep.1, but some of the tracks can still be repetetive as hell and some just sound bad like oil deserts act 2 and act 3 music. The game, belive it or not, also has local and online multiplayer were ojne of you controls sonic and the other Tails. I havent triend it myself coz no one plays this game much anymore but if playing this game with a friend or online appears to you then by all means do so. There are also red rings to collect in the stages but iunless your an achevement lover then don't bother as you don't need to collect then to prroceed and they dont unlock anything extra. The ♥♥♥♥?

Also if you have both Ep. 1 and Ep.2 on the some system you get a special 'lock on' extra in the form of Episode Metal. You play as Metal sonic (he controls exactly the same btw) through 4 of the stages from ep.1 and it explains how metal sonic returned from Sonic CD. Its nothing special at all and it should only take you about 15 minuits to finish. So basicly Eggman by the power of pointing powers up Metal Sonic and by being rebuilt in Mad Gear and absorbing some purple void in lost labyrinth zone hes fully restores and he flies off and meets Sonic and Tails in white park. Huzzar???

Well Sonic 4: Episode 2 in my opinion is a much better game when conpaired to Episode 1. Better graphics, better physicls, cirtenly better level design and overall is a much more enjoyable experience. At £9.99 i do think that is asking maybe a bit much for this game and I do wish the bosses were better and their be less springs and speed boosters but if you want a light hearted sonic game then go for it.

The music is still great, the physics and mechanics have been tweaked to be much better, and with Tails in tow, you have a lot of options to get through each stage. The stages are fun, the bosses are great, especially the fights with Metal Sonic, and overall it's a great 2D Sonic game. It's still a little more like Sonic Rush than the Genesis games, but it's a little more in the middle of the two. The big problem I have is the Special Stages. I've beaten them all, and while Super Sonic leads to major catharsis factor, the stages are the most frustrating part of the game. They start off fine, like Sonic 2's stages with proper control, but you will need a guide and a lot of patience for the later ones. Here's a tip: if you approach the goal and don't have enough rings, pause before you step over the goal, and hit restart to try the stage again as much as you want. I'll give this one a 9.0 out of 10. One of the better Sonic games.

Sonic 4 - Ep. I wasn't too great. The use of Tails as a mandatory character is one that is met with a lot of controversy but I found it to do more harm than good - *especially* during some of the boss fights. There was one level in Oil Desert Zone where you had to fly a long distance using him and it sucked so bad that I felt it worth noting specifically in this review, but fortunately that's the only time during a normal level I found myself wanting to toss my mouse across the room due to the stupidity of it - special stages are a different story, however, but I'll delve into that later. All in all, though, he did create a few problems when he was mandatory but I ultimately found he did more good than harm.

The stages are generally very well done, barring a couple of exceptions, and while some of the bosses can have patterns that are a bit too vague I found them to be acceptable for the most part, yet none of them were too memorable barring Sky Fortress Zone's boss and the final boss.

I'd put this game higher than Sonic 1 and S4 Ep. I, but it's definitely weaker than S3&K, SCD, and S2. It's got a lot of good moments, however, and I can definitely recommend picking it up while it's on sale.

reviewText:
Despite not completely following the formula that was established in Sonic 1, 2 & 3(and Knuckles) It's still a very functional game that perhaps is more catered to a slightly more modern audience, since the classic games play in a more 1990s sort of fashion. You can feel the difference with a lighter Sonic and feels a bit more fluid than in previous 2D games. So for long time Sonic fans you may still be thrown off by the unfaithful physics that don't reflect the old-school days of 2D Sonic, but they are a step up from what Episode I had to offer because of some added tweaks to the game engine and, and some subtle changes to Sonic in this game too, such as how he no longer uncurls out of a Spin when jumping of a slope.
So the game handles quite well in my opinion, despite not really playing like the Genesis/Mega-Drive days.
Tails controls well too, and the implementation of team based gameplay is executed well too, so I have no real issues there.

Now content is important, as Sonic 3 & Knuckles was a big game(s), and Sonic 4 Episode II on its own isn't veyr massive, and the locations of zones like in Episode I are virtually all tributes to zones from the Genesis days, but there's much more to do in Sonic 3. And since Episode II is a seperate game that you have to pay for individually (and with Sonic 3 and Sonic & Knuckles it's easy to buy the two games together) Sonic 4 Episode II doesn't offer too much a sequel since it doesn't really expand but rather just pay a homage to Classic Sonic, so if you we're hoping to see more than what Sonic 3 & Knuckles offered, then even with both episodes combined, you won't really get that here.

However it's still a fun game that any fan of Sonic should give a go, and can even appeal to people who aren't necessarily fans of Sonic. It's not amazing, but a good game nontheless.

When I was younger I was a sonic fan and I own all Genesis/Megadrive, Mastersystem and Dreamcast Sonic games even today. My favorite game was Sonic 3 & Knuckles but sadly Sonic 4 is a HUGE disappointment.

The physics and controls are not the same as the previous games, they try to behave the same but they kinda... feel fake.

The combo moves are pretty much required to complete a stage, they aren't that bad but it's one of those tiny annoying things that force you to slow down since you're REQUIRED to use them to progress like it or not.

Level design on this one is between good-and-terrible, there's a part in Oil Desert Zone that is very unforgiving. This episode is clearly harder than Episode 1... sometimes way too hard like the last boss of the game.

Boss fights thankfully are not a reboot of any boss from early games so there's a bit of originality and creativity here but fighting them can actually become tedious of how long it takes to beat them.

Length of the game it's too short, yeah I know it's just 1 of 2 episodes, but that strategy was just to cash in on the same game twice.

Overall, this game wasn't clearly designed by the original team behind the previous games (I should appreciate more info about this).

In resume:

PROS:
* Well... Sonic? And Tails!
* Nice 3D visuals
* 2D Gameplay
* No cutscenes
* No new characters to fill yet more the Sonic universe.
* Team work combos, including a similar one that was in Sonic 3
* Original, strong and difficult bosses

CONS:
* Fake physics & controls regarding the previous titles.
* Nothing significantly new in gameplay apart of the combos
* Too short, only 5+Special Zones, Sonic 2 has 11+Special
* Team work combos being REQUIRED to finish a stage
* Last boss is waaaay too dificult for a sonic game

If you want a modern sonic game that is good go get Sonic Generations instead.

PS: I don't dislike the game, I find it OKAY-ISH, but i can't really recommend it as a sequel to the old ones.
